website_content.content:
Hacker News new | past | comments | ask | show | jobs | submit	login
snarfy on Dec 5, 2018 | parent | context | favorite | on: Thieves boosting signal from key fobs inside homes...
> Key fobs are constantly broadcasting a signal that communicates with a specific vehicle, he said, and when it comes into a close enough range, the vehicle will open and start.
Why is it transmitting without the user pressing a button? Is that a feature? As you walk up to the car it automatically starts like magic? I'm not familiar with these newer cars.
wsh on Dec 5, 2018 | next 
Yes, it’s a feature, so you don’t have to remove the key from a bag or pocket to enter or start the car.
In typical designs, the car continually transmits a low-frequency (e.g., 135 kHz) radio signal to wake up any wireless keys within range. When a key receives this signal, it replies with a VHF (e.g., 315 MHz) signal, and the car unlocks or starts when a door is opened or the start button is pressed.
The reply signal, at least, is uniquely coded to the car. The attack is to extend the range of the LF wake-up signal, causing a key stored away from the car to transmit a valid reply.
In some models, besides the transponder described above, the key also has a passive RFID tag, which works with a reader in the car to allow starting even if the battery in the key is dead.
(The article is wrong about the broadcasts, by the way; if the key transmitted continually, its battery wouldn’t last long.)
ryandrake on Dec 5, 2018 | parent | next 
This is insane. Please tell me this is an option that non-insane consumers can get their car without. Fortunately I drive an old car so this does not affect me—yet. If I ever have to replace mine, this looks like yet-another-misfeature I’ll have to look out for to avoid.
whyaduck on Dec 5, 2018...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Hacker News is a social news website focusing primarily on computer science and entrepreneurship-related articles. It enables a wide variety of discussions and is frequented by informed users who often share credible information. While the community can provide valuable insights, much of the content is user-generated, making some discussions less reliable than professional journalism. The site is good for trends in technology, but specific automotive claims may need deeper verification.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses how key fobs communicate with vehicles using radio waves, specifically mentioning low-frequency wake-up signals from the car and the VHF reply from the fob. It implies the existence of a propagation mechanism, which could correlate with the claim that holding a fob to one's head increases its range by acting as an amplifier. It does not delve deeply into the mechanics but hints at the basic principles involved that could explain the phenomenon.

website_content.content:
How Do Key Fobs Work? - John M Jennings
=============== 
!     
]
*   
    *   
*   
    *   
*   
    *   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Select Page
How Do Key Fobs Work?
---------------------
by  | Aug 16, 2019
!
!
**Key fobs for remotely locking/unlocking car doors are standard equipment at this point** and **keyless ignitions using key fob recognition is now standard in over 60% of new car models** according to Edmonds. Future generations won’t know that we used to use actual keys to unlock and start our cars.
Key fobs transmit a radio signal to the car and if the car recognizes the transmission as coming from the right fob(s) it will perform the command encoded in the radio transmission.
**All key fobs of U.S. manufacturers use a radio signal frequency of 315 MHz** and foreign models us 433.92 MHz. Because all fobs use just one of two frequencies, **the security relies on both the fob (transmitter) and car electronics (receiver) knowing the same code which changes after every press of the key fob button** (or otherwise communicating with each other). Both the transmitter and receiver know the code numbers as they change because they are **programmed with the same code generating algorithm.** So, both the car and fob know what code number will be next due to sharing an algorithm.
The mathematics of the quasi-randomly generated codes is that it is **about a one-in-a-billion chance that a car would mistakenly unlock** because of a duplicate code transmission from a wrong fob.
**What happens if you press the key fob button when you aren’t in range of the car?** Now the car receiver and fob transmitter are no longer in sync as the fob will move one code number ahead of the car receiver. This...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This website appears to be a personal blog by author John M. Jennings, which focuses on various topics. The credibility and accuracy vary since it heavily depends on personal opinion and anecdotal evidence. Without professional standards or peer review, the information cannot be fully trusted, particularly for scientific or technical claims like those regarding key fob technology.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source explains the frequencies used by key fobs and how they transmit signals to the car, but it does not provide scientific principles that would directly explain the claim about holding a fob to one’s head. It establishes a basic understanding of key fob functionality but stops short of clarifying any amplification effects.

Car Hacking - The ECU and protocols like CANbus have become the heart and brain of most modern cars, but it has also become a locked down black box. This is a place for people interested in taking back control of the car they bought. New age hot rodders, ECOmodders, Security researchers, the curious, the paranoid, and the tinkerers are all welcome. We encourage the use of open source solutions and tools like arduino and rasberry pi.

Any good ways to protect a key fob signal when locking and unlocking a vehicle?
===============================================================================
I know about faraday pouches that protect the key fob when it's not in use. However, is there any way to help protect the key fob signal when locking and unlocking the car? I guess this is assuming that there isn't two-way authentication between the car and the key fob, which im not sure if that is implemented or not.

metatags.og:title: Should a key-fob be stored a metal coffee can?
metatags.og:description: I’m having difficulty understanding this key fob security issue.  I can see how a thief could intercept the fob’s radio signal with speciality equipment  when you press the door-open or engine-start button, and then use that signal to open your car’s door and drive the car away.     But I don’t see how storing the fob in a metal can when it isn’t being used would be of any  help.  Anybody here have an explanation?

website_content.content:
I’m having difficulty understanding this key fob security issue.  I can see how a thief could intercept the fob’s radio signal with speciality equipment  when you press the door-open or engine-start button, and then use that signal to open your car’s door and drive the car away.     But I don’t see how storing the fob in a metal can when it isn’t being used would be of any  help.  Anybody here have an explanation?
Crimes committed by tech-savvy car thieves using special tools purchased on the internet are contributing to a spike vehicle thefts.
With some cars, you don’t press a button on the fob to unlock the car; you just walk up to the car. The fob is clearly transmitting all of the time (although intermittently, I’m sure).
As for the metal can, look up a Faraday shield if you’ve never heard of that, although you’d probably need a metal lid to complete the enclosure.
I’ve said it before…but I sure miss plain ol’ metal keys.

website_content.content:
It would be amazing if one could use the Flipper as a backup car key, not to mention a huge money saver compared to buying another key from the dealership.
Potentially multiple frequencies. Unclear if there is a use case for push to start literally pressing on the ignition vs. the other key functions (former works with no battery in FOB).
Info on RF modulation and if it’s possible to store multiple “keys” to use the Flipper as a backup key - broadly I think that captures it and would be a HUGE money saver
I’m not sure on the last one, but the only other category calling out other frequencies didn’t look best suited at a glance.
There’s a complication of “Rolling Codes” used by car keys that I don’t fully understand how difficult it would be to emulate a key using a Flipper. Unclear if you could brute force it to work or if a single incorrect “reply” starts the entire process over again.

website_content.content:
**Posts:** 
**Joined:** Sun Feb 25, 2007 5:39 pm
**Location:** Northern VA
### 
 by **** » Thu Sep 28, 2023 7:26 am
I purchased a new 2023 Honda Accord. The key FOBs come with the ability to start the car by way of push button. I've learned that the signals from the key FOBs can be captured and programmed to steal the car. To prevent this there are options have the FOB wrapped in aluminum foil, use a faraday bag or a tin can. I purchased the faraday bags.
From the YouTube channels on Toyotas, another option is to turn the transmitting off with two clicks. I could not find any information on Hondas about doing the same thing. The Honda message boards are no where near as active as the Toyotas. The Honda salesman and parts department are of no help.
Last edited by  on Thu Sep 28, 2023 7:31 am, edited 1 time in total.

website_content.content:
I agree that it won’t be fast enough to catch quick burst transmissions that are just “floating in the air”, or that one might be trying to sniff at random.
But in other cases, like the remote I have, you can just hold down the button and the signal keeps sending. In cases like what I’m trying (where it’s a generic remote with no codes printed on it) and I can keep the button depressed. A somewhat slow scan should still pick up the frequency eventually.
In the case of  original question where he knows the frequencies. Changing the Read RAW to be more configurable (allowing fine grain tuning of possible frequencies in say 1MHz or 5MHz increments) would provide a better way to capture the specific signals.
this approach was chosen for the frequency analyzer is not a good life. understand cc1101 is first of all just a receiver and not an SDR, it cannot scan and capture a signal in a wide range, but only receive it at a set frequency. at the same time, the switching speed from frequency to a new one with all calibrations and RSSI reading takes at least 3ms + to accurately determine the carrier, it switches to a narrow channel of the receiving filter and scans the found frequency again to determine the exact one. this is about 50 frequency scans. i.e. 150ms. car key fobs and all kinds of weather stations, switches, etc. do not transmit a signal for a long time, but only 4-8 parcels. 1 Keelog packet lasts about 80ms + - that is, 4 about 320-500ms. and if you scan the entire allowed range in 1 MHz steps (5 you will definitely miss the signal), you simply will not get to the moment when there is a transmission. and again there will be talk that the analyzer does not work. now you just need to add to the list all the frequencies that are used by various systems and everyone will be happy.
 that all makes sense!
That’s why I...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... (nothing concrete) about how these types of fobs work. Some suggest they're "always transmitting", while others say the car always interrogates, which wakes the fob up when in range. Considering the size of a fob's battery, to me it would not make sense for it to be always on, as this would deplete a CR2032 in no time. The interrogation/response seems like a more viable solution ... but ... I wouldn't know for sure.
    –  ♦
    Commented May 24, 2022 at 12:01
  | 
1 Answer 1
----------
Sorted by: 
Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first)
0
My wife has a 2018 Honda CRV and the remote fob is always transmitting without pressing any of the key fob buttons. As I walk up to the car the doors will automatically unlock, so it is always transmitting an RF signal. The automatic door unlock is a user option I setup in the vehicle settings. If your Kia does the same you could rent or buy an anti-spy/bug detector. These devices can pickup RF signals from 1 MHz-8 GHz or greater. The purchase cost is ~ $50.
Follow

metatags.twitter:title: Why should you keep your key fob in a metal (coffee) can? To prevent car theft. How it works
metatags.og:title: Why should you keep your key fob in a metal (coffee) can? To prevent car theft. How it works
metatags.og:description: Crimes committed by tech-savvy car thieves using special tools purchased on the internet are contributing to a spike vehicle thefts.
metatags.twitter:creator: @freep
metatags.article:author: Phoebe Wall Howard
metatags.twitter:description: Crimes committed by tech-savvy car thieves using special tools purchased on the internet are contributing to a spike vehicle thefts.

website_content.content:
A top global cybersecurity expert says the threat of car theft now is greater than ever and urges taking simple precautions to prevent car owners from becoming victims of tech-savvy criminals.
Thieves have perfected the art of stealing the code from that key fob sitting on a kitchen counter or hung on a hook by the door. And tools that make theft fast and easy can be purchased on the internet. Worse, the latest theft devices allow criminals to amplify a vehicle's radio signal so that thieves can better access and copy the key fob signal to steal a vehicle
"The problem is, this is not a story, it's reality," Moshe Shlisel, a veteran of the Israeli Air Force and now CEO of GuardKnox Cyber Technologies, told the Detroit Free Press by phone from his office in Ramla, Israel.
This whole situation revolves around "smart" key systems that use nonsecure commercial radio waves to signal when the key fob is near or inside the vehicle, he said. These key fobs allow car owners to unlock the door, start the engine or even open the trunk from far away. But that's not all.
"You may think of your car key as little more than a tool to start the car. But have you ever considered that it may also be the best tool to prevent your car from being stolen?" says AAA on its .
!
How thieves car-hack victims
----------------------------
Car thieves...[Content truncated]

While they focus on local news, they cover a variety of topics, including automotive news, reflecting the industry's importance in the region. Articles are generally well-researched and fact-checked, making it a good source for credible information, including claims about key fobs.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source discusses issues related to key fob security that could indirectly relate to signal amplification. It suggests that the convenience of smart key fobs relies on their ability to transmit signals over a distance but does not specifically address the role of body position in increasing range.
